question: Question_B_03_(a)
statement:
Let \emph{A} be a certain $2\times 3$ matrix. Suppose that using
elementary row operations, the matrix \emph{A} can be transformed into
the matrix

\begin{align*}U = \begin{bmatrix} 
1 & 0 & -7 \\
0 & 1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

Find all solutions, if any, of the system $Ax = 0$
sols:
Elementary row operations don't change the solution of a homogeneous
equation, hence the solutions of \emph{Ux = 0} also solve \emph{Ax = 0}.

From the first row on matrix U, we have
$\mathbf{x_{1}} = 7\mathbf{x_{3}}$.

From the second row on matrix U, we have
$\mathbf{x_{2}} = -4\mathbf{x_{3}}$.

Hence the general solution to is
$\begin{bmatrix}\mathbf{x_{1}}\\ \mathbf{x_{2}}\\ \mathbf{x_{3}}\end{bmatrix} = a\begin{bmatrix}7\\
-4\\1\end{bmatrix}$, where a is any real number.
hints:
The matrix \emph{U} describes a system of two equations and three
unknowns. Hence the homogeneous system has at least one free parameter,
and hence infinitely many solutions.
